declarations.comments: An adaptor allowing `>$<` to map over the inputs of a comparison function.
declarations.title: Comparison

declarations.comments: The default comparison for any values with an `Ord` instance.
declarations.title: defaultComparison

declarations.comments:
`Divide` is the contravariant analogue of `Apply`.

For example, to test equality of `Point`s, we can use the `Divide` instance
for `Equivalence`:

```purescript
type Point = Tuple Int Int

pointEquiv :: Equivalence Point
pointEquiv = divided defaultEquivalence defaultEquivalence
```
declarations.title: Divide

declarations.comments:
An adaptor allowing `>$<` to map over the inputs of an equivalence
relation.
declarations.title: Equivalence

declarations.comments: The default equivalence relation for any values with an `Eq` instance.
declarations.title: defaultEquivalence

declarations.comments:
A `Contravariant` functor can be seen as a way of changing the input type
of a consumer of input, in contrast to the standard covariant `Functor`
that can be seen as a way of changing the output type of a producer of
output.

`Contravariant` instances should satisfy the following laws:

- Identity `cmap id = id`
- Composition `cmap f <<< cmap g = cmap (g <<< f)`
declarations.title: Contravariant

declarations.comments: As all `Contravariant` functors are also trivially `Invariant`, this function can be used as the `imap` implementation for any types that have an existing `Contravariant` instance.
declarations.title: imapC

declarations.comments: The opposite of the function category.
declarations.title: Op

declarations.comments: An adaptor allowing `>$<` to map over the inputs of a predicate.
declarations.title: Predicate
